I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Since independence Tajikistan has been implementing reforms that included eliminating 
price controls, lifting tariff barriers, and privatizing small enterprises. These efforts together with 
the end of civil conflict, macroeconomic recovery, and strong remittances contributed to  strong 
gross domestic product (GDP) growth (about 9% average per annum during 2001–2006), with 
modest inflation and a stable exchange rate. The Government is now embarking on a more 
comprehensive  reform  program  that  includes  reforming  state  institutions  and  public 
administration, and private sector development (PSD). In March 2006, the Government adopted 
the Public Administration Reform Strategy.     
 
2.  The Government, with the help of the Donor Coordination Council, developed the Private 
Sector Development Strategy (PSDS) in 2006. The PSDS is aimed at improving government 
policies and laws that are the greatest impediment to investment and PSD. The PSDS consists 
of four elements: (i) reducing risk and uncertainty for the potential investor or entrepreneur, (ii) 
removing  barriers  that  actually  prevent  entry,  (iii)  reducing  the  cost  of  doing  business  in 
Tajikistan including entry and exit costs, and (iv) supporting the private sector to increase 
productivity and human capacity to drive growth. 
 
3.  The Government established the State Committee on Investments and State Property 
Management  (SCISPM)  during  structural  reorganization  of  the  government  in  late  2006. 
Supporting development of the private sector and attraction of foreign direct investments are 
among the key functions of SCISPM, enabling it to potentially play a major role in implementing 
the PSDS. However, the institutional capacity of SCISPM in fulfilling its responsibilities is weak 
and requires major technical assistance. 
 
4.  In 2006, the Government requested aid agencies to provide assistance for implementing 
the PSDS. Accordingly, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) fielded its Fact-Finding Mission1 
from 30 April to 10 May; that led to an understanding with the Government on the impact, 
outcomes,  outputs,  approach,  cost  estimates,  implementation  arrangements,  and  terms  of 
reference  of  the  technical  assistance  Implementation  Support  for  the  Private  Sector 
Development Strategy in Tajikistan (TA).2 The Department for International Development (DFID) 
of the United Kingdom would cofinance the TA. The design and monitoring framework is in 
Appendix 1.  The design of the TA has been closely coordinated with the planned assistance of 
other development partners, especially the European Commission (EC) and the World Bank 
(WB)  group.    The  European  Bank  for  Reconstruction  and  Development  (EBRD)  facilitated 
Mission consultations with the private sector and commercial banks and contributed to the 
design of the TA. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
5.  Tajikistan ranks 133 out of 175 countries in the WB’s Doing Business in 2006.3 The 
private sector’s share in GDP grew slightly to 43% in 2005 from 40% in 2004, but still remains 
low by international or even regional standards. Unfavorable investment climate is increasingly

becoming a binding constraint to sustainable economic growth. In response, the Government 
has identified PSD as a strategic development priority for Tajikistan. The Poverty Reduction 
Strategy for 2007–2009 aims at increasing the share of the private sector to 55% by 2009.      
 
6.  Increased  growth  of  small  producers  was  recorded  in  recent  years.  Growth  was 
particularly strong in the traditional "small business"4 areas like construction, retail trade, and 
catering. There are, however, numerous obstacles to stronger growth and greater dynamism of 
the private sector. They include (i) the Government’s insufficient understanding of its role as an 
“enabler” of the PSD, (ii) multiple and often ill-designed registration and inspection requirements, 
(iii) an inadequate legal framework and the judicial system, (iv) weak public administration; (v) 
weak infrastructure  particularly in energy and transport, and (vi) an underdeveloped financial 
system. Lack of profitable investment opportunities due to the small size of the economy5 and 
limited physical access to export markets also constrain private sector development in Tajikistan. 
Improvements in transport infrastructure and cross-border trading arrangements would help 
alleviate these constraints in the long term. In the interim, industry-level solutions could be found 
through better quality information on markets and technology. 
       
7.  SCISPM staff has been drawn largely from the previous State Agency for Antimonopoly, 
Aid  Coordination  Unit  under  the  President’s  Office  and  the  State  Property  Management 
Committee.  SCISPM  also  recruited  professionals  from  National  Social  Investment  Fund  of 
Tajikistan and other aid-funded projects. The management of SCISPM consists of a team of 
experienced government officials drawn from  various government institutions, including the 
central  bank  and  former  ministry  of  economy  and  trade.  A  quick  capacity  assessment  of 
SCISPM in Supplementary Appendix A suggests a need for review of its regulation (charter) 
and organizational structure, and for building the capacity of its staff to shift the focus from 
control  of  the  private  sector  to  providing  an  enabling  environment  for  the  private  sector. 
Legislative and policy reforms to improve the climate for the PSD are urgently needed. The 
capacity of SCISPM to coordinate the drafting of relevant legislation and its approval needs 
building up.    
 
8.  In  the  initial  stages  of  PSD,  institutional  strengthening  of  business  promotion  and 
advisory services strongly complements policy reforms for an enabling environment. Modern 
business education is absent in Tajikistan and significant support and advisory services are 
required for the private sector to attract financing and develop. For example, commercial banks 
in Tajikistan avoid long-term lending to the private sector and when they do lend for the short 
term, they tend to demand high levels of collateral. Therefore, there is a strong need to create 
some success stories of enterprises that demonstrate improved operational, marketing, and 
financial results to make Tajik enterprises attractive as an investment class and provide an 
incentive for banks and potential investors to increase lending to this sector.  
 
9.  PSD is a key operational priority of ADB and is one of the three crosscutting themes of 
the  Long-Term  Strategic  Framework  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (2001–2015).  For 
sustaining  high  growth,  employment  creation,  and  rising  production,  the  Private  Sector 
Development Strategy of ADB operationalizes the Bank’s strategies and visions through three 
main thrusts: (i) help governments of the developing member countries to create enabling 
conditions  for  PSD,  (ii)  generate  private  sector  investment  opportunities,  and  (iii)  catalyze 
private investment. The proposed TA will address the first and third pillars of PSD.

10.  With its sector expertise and multilateral structure, ADB can serve as an effective partner 
for the Government in initiating, implementing, and coordinating PSD-related analysis, policy 
dialogue, capacity development, and reform  design and implementation, toward supporting 
private sector-led growth. The translation of the PSDS matrix into actions must be facilitated 
through continuous engagement and dialogue, and effective change management. At the same 
time the private sector must be engaged with a view to select and nurture a limited number of 
most promising businesses. The TA can better achieve its outcomes by supporting reform 
champions and creating demonstration effects.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The TA aims to improve the capacity of the Government in promoting PSD. The main 
intended outcomes of the TA are (i) the Government’s understanding  of its role as an “enabler” 
of the private sector, (ii) effective engagement and active leadership of the Government in 
simplifying  business  regulations  and  creating  a  favorable  environment  for  PSD,  and  (iii) 
mainstreaming  and  strengthening  of  business  promotion  and  advisory  services  by  the 
Government.  
 
12.  The expected outputs of the TA include (i) policy advice including that for coordination of 
PSDS implementation, (ii) assessment and development of the Government’s capacity for PSD, 
and (iii) development of a concept of investment and business promotion for Tajikistan and 
business advisory assistance to a few businesses for demonstration purposes. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  Implementation of the TA would be closely coordinated with the planned support of other 
development assistance partners. DfID, which is cofinancing the TA, would also be involved 
during TA implementation. A working group comprising SCISPM and development partners (the 
working group) would be set up to oversee the management of external assistance, including 
that for the TA for PSDS implementation. The TA will assist the Government to lead aid 
coordination in PSD through the proposed working group.  
 
14.  The TA will have three tasks. A more detailed set of activities under each task are in 
Appendix 1. The set of activities will be further refined in a participatory manner in consultation 
with the working group during the 3-month inception phase.  
   
  1.  Policy Advice and Coordination for PSD Strategy Implementation 
 
15.  This task would entail providing expert advice to SCISPM on implementing the PSDS, 
coordinating government and development partner support for PSD, and identifying resource 
gaps and helping SCISPM address those gaps.   
 
  2.  Capacity Building 
 
16.  Capacity building will be at two levels, namely, institutional and human development. It 
should result in (i) creating robust mechanisms for implementing the PSDS, and (ii) building in 
different government institutions a greater awareness of the government's role in PSD. Building 
individual and institutional capabilities of SCISPM, including through reorganization, to fulfill its

4   
mandate to support PSD, will be an important part of this task. This component will complement 
and build on relevant capacity-building activities assisted by other development partners. 
 
  3.  Business Development and Investment Promotion Support 
 
17.  This task would lead to the development and implementation of a business development 
and  investment  promotion  concept,  taking  into  account  the  relevant  experience  of  other 
countries, principles of market economy and transparency, and the importance of avoiding the 
creation of additional bureaucratic structures.     
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The estimated TA cost is $2,000,000 equivalent, of which $900,000 will be financed on a 
grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. The Government of the United Kingdom has agreed 
to contribute $1,000,000 equivalent on a grant basis. ADB will administer the contribution from 
the  Government  of  the  United  Kingdom.  The  Government  of  Tajikistan  will  contribute  the 
balance of $100,000 equivalent in kind by providing office accommodation, and remuneration 
and per diem of counterpart government staff. The TA costs and the financing plan are in 
Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  SCISPM will be the Executing Agency of the TA under the overall coordination of the 
President’s Office of Tajikistan. The TA will be implemented by a team of individual national and 
international  consultants.  The  input  will  comprise  54  person-months  of  international  and 
72 person-months of national consulting services. Outline terms of reference for the consultants 
are in Appendix 3. ADB will engage the consultants (both national and international) on an 
individual basis in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended 
from time to time). The consultants will be located at SCISPM. Equipment under the TA will be 
procured by ADB in accordance with its Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time 
to time) and will be transferred to SCISPM upon completion of the TA. The TA is estimated to 
start in October 2007 and be completed in October 2010.  
 
E.  Monitoring and Reporting  
20.  The consultants will submit to ADB, SCISPM, and the working group an inception report 
at the end of the 3-month inception phase. The inception report will  
(i) include a detailed work plan for the project team and the implementation plan of the 
TA;  
(ii) assess the current capacity of SCISPM in relation to its mandate to support PSD; 
(iii)  identify  key  success  factors  supported  by  the  TA,  including  a  monitoring  and 
evaluation plan; and  
(iv)develop  a  strategy  for  communicating  and  coordinating  TA  implementation  with 
related activities of other development partners and government agencies.   
 
21.  Thereafter, the consultants will submit to ADB, SCISPM, and the working group progress 
reports every 6 months and a final report on the activities, outputs, and results of all TA tasks. 
The second 6-month report will include a detailed action plan for implementing the PSDS, 
including a set of quantitative and qualitative performance indicators of SCISPM’s progress in 
implementing the strategy.

5
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Government of the United Kingdom, and (ii) ADB providing the 
balance not exceeding the equivalent of $900,000 on a grant basis, to the Government of 
Tajikistan for Implementation Support for Private Sector Development Strategy in Tajikistan, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The outline terms of reference for consultants describe the main tasks in each of the output 
categories of the program of activities under the technical assistance (TA) as attached to the 
design and monitoring framework, as well as support in project management. Consultants will 
ensure that all work and outputs under the TA fully comply with all relevant Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) policies and guidelines. 
 
2.  In general, the required areas of expertise for international and national experts include (i) 
implementation  of  private  sector  development  (PSD)  strategies  and  policies,  (ii)  institutional 
change, (iii) business development and investment promotion, (iv) legal and regulatory reform, (v) 
capacity building, and (vi) PSD monitoring and evaluation. Experience in working in the region in 
the captioned areas will be taken into account.        
 
A.  Private Sector Development Policy and Capacity Building Specialist/Team Leader 
(international, 25 person-months) 
 
3.  The primary responsibility of the specialist will be assisting the government in creating an 
enabling  environment  for  PSD,  which  would  include  (i)  reducing  risk  and  uncertainty  for  the 
potential  investor  or  entrepreneur,  (ii)  removing  barriers  that  actually  prevent  entry,  and  (iii) 
reducing the cost of doing business in Tajikistan, including entry and exit costs.  
 
4.  The specialist will have an advanced degree in economic and business management, law 
or a related discipline, and extensive work experience in PSD and conducting policy dialogue with 
decision makers at the highest levels of government and the private sector. The specialist will be 
an expert on issues such as sequencing of PSD and creating conducive business environments; 
issues related to property rights, legal and regulatory frameworks, taxes, customs and duties, 
access to finance and banking as well as other PSD-relevant and sector-specific issues. The 
specialist should preferably have experience working in the region in the captioned areas. The 
team leader will be responsible for all outputs of the TA and will guide all consultants. The following 
are the main tasks. 
 
(i)  Provide  expert  advice  to  the  Government  on  implementing  the  private  sector 
development strategy (PSDS) and its recommendations. 
(ii)  Help State Committee on Investments and State Property Management (SCISPM) 
take the lead in coordinating government and external support for PSD in line with 
the priorities and approaches set out in the PSDS. 
(iii)  Help SCISPM identify the resource gaps and coordinate work with the development 
partners in addressing these gaps in the short and medium term. 
(iv)  Carry out a comprehensive analysis of SCISPM’s capacity-building needs, assess 
the  institutional  framework  required  to  successfully  implement  the  PSDS,  and 
propose a capacity-building plan of actions to be funded and implemented under 
this TA. 
(v)  Prepare a comprehensive framework outlining a sequenced set of policy reforms to 
implement the PSDS.  
(vi)  Assist SCISPM and work closely together with all other authorities to carefully adjust 
and re-engineer individual legal processes so that they become less burdensome to 
investors without compromising other policy objectives. 
(vii)  Help  SCISPM  compile  and  produce  a  guide  for  potential  entrepreneurs  and 
investors on how to set up a business (including joint venture) in Tajikistan.

(viii)  Produce a green book on best practices in investment promotion and facilitation for 
Tajikistan that would be used by the Government. 
(ix)  Draft a new generic model of a bilateral investment treaty ensuring that it meets 
Tajikistan’s development objectives and investment priorities, including those stated 
in the Poverty Reduction Strategy and National Development Strategy as well as 
contemporary developments in international investment rule making. 
(x)  Design, in a participatory manner, a set of quantitative and qualitative performance 
indicators on SCISPM’s progress for adoption and ownership by the Government.   
(xi)  Prepare and provide an inception report, 6-monthly performance reports, and a final 
report  on  the  activities,  outputs,  and  results  of  all  TA  tasks  for  submission  to 
SCISPM and ADB. 
 
B.  Business Development Service and Market Access Specialist (international, 29 person-
months) 
 
5.  The  primary  responsibility  of  the  specialist  will  be  to  provide  customized,  hands-on 
assistance to selected Tajik companies so as to prepare them to qualify for investment deals and 
to develop successful, sustainable business practices after the investment.  
 
6.  The  specialist  will  have  a  higher  degree  in  development  economics,  business 
administration,  or  a  related  discipline  and  up  to  5  years  hands-on  experience  in  business 
development, experience on the ground, and strong networks within the business community. The 
specialist should preferably have the experience of working in the region in the captioned areas.  
The tasks are the following. 
 
(i)  Assess,  develop,  and  implement  the  business  development  and  investment 
promotion part of the TA.  
(ii)  Develop a concept of investment and business promotion for Tajikistan. 
(iii)  Identify prospective Tajik and foreign investors looking for joint-venture partners, 
through detailed firm-specific research.  
(iv)  Gain audience with decision makers in these companies so that sales presentations 
could be conducted. 
(v)  Design  and  implement  firm-specific  investment  missions  from  Tajikistan  to  the 
source country and vice versa.  
(vi)  Conduct firm-specific research followed by sales presentations and seminars.  
(vii)  Provide investment counseling services to the firms.  
(viii)  Expedite the processing of business plans, applications, and permits. 
(ix)  Access the information technology services offered by the Government to support 
enterprise development, and recommend how to improve market information and 
market  intelligence  for  enterprises;  recommend  additional  support  to  improve 
access of enterprises to the domestic and international markets. 
(x)  Conduct a supply-chain analysis to determine constraints to the production and 
distribution of goods and services. 
(xi)  Provide inputs to reports on the activities, outputs, and results of all TA tasks for 
submission to SCISPM and ADB. 
 
C.  Project Coordinator/Legal Expert (national, 36 person-months) 
 
7.  The  expert  will  have  a  degree  in  law,  business,  or  a  related  discipline  with  working 
experience in the PSD policy, legal, and regulatory field. The expert will be responsible for the 
following main tasks.

12  Appendix 3 
 
(i)  Advise SCISPM on simplification of the regulatory framework for PSD, taking into 
account  best international practices. 
(ii)  Identify, structure, and arrange partnership arrangements with local organizations 
that are involved with policy and regulatory reform, including business associations, 
government authorities, policy-focused nongovernment organizations, and related 
government and aid agency programs.   
(iii)  Assist the team leader to lead and coordinate the work of the team of national and 
international consultants in close collaboration with the Government and under the 
overall leadership of ADB. 
(iv)  Advise  and  assist  in  developing  qualitative  and  quantitative  processes  and 
performance indicators for PSDS implementation, within the overall time frame of the 
TA. 
(v)  Assist the team leader to monitor performance and assess TA impact. 
(vi)  Assist and coordinate in organizing training, workshops, seminars, and conferences. 
(vii)  Provide inputs to written reports at the end of each phase of the TA process. 
(viii)  Participate in preparing a final TA report on the activities, outputs, and results of all 
TA components for submission to SCISPM and ADB. 
(ix)  Administer the day-to-day work of the office and office staff. 
(x)  Provide inputs to the reports on the activities, outputs, and results of all TA tasks for 
submission to SCISPM and ADB. 
 
D.  Business Development Service and Market Access Development Specialist (national, 
36 person-months) 
 
8.  The specialist will be responsible for the following main tasks. 
 
(i)  Prepare feasibility studies or project profiles in specific growth firms/sectors and 
package the studies so that they could be used in SCISPM investment-generating 
missions. 
(ii)  Prepare materials for consulting services to prospective Tajik and foreign investors 
looking for joint-venture partners. 
(iii)  Coordinate SCISPM investment-generating missions to source countries.  
(iv)  Provide on-the-job training for SCISPM personnel.  
(v)  Identify issues impacting on growth and development of enterprises and explore 
solutions.  
(vi)  In consultation with enterprises, advise the Government on any issues affecting 
enterprises. 
(vii)  Assist and advise on a quick and simple documentation and clearance process for 
imports and exports. 
(viii)  Provide inputs to the reports on the activities, outputs, and results of all TA tasks for 
submission to SCISPM and ADB.
